properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blowing snow reducing visibilities over the Haines-Skagway Road today. A Pacific storm is moving across the Haines-Skagway Road today. A combination of falling snow and southerly winds gusting to 60 - 80 km/h will produce blowing snow and limited visibilities today. The strongest winds and lowest visibilities will occur near Chilkat Pass. The strong winds and blowing snow will continue through to this evening before abating. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-02T05:14:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-01T15:04:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1634034283.2020
Area: Haines Road - Haines Junction to Pleasant Camp
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blowing snow reducing visibilities over the Haines-Skagway Road today. A Pacific storm is moving across the Haines-Skagway Roads today. A combination of falling snow and southerly winds gusting to 60 - 80 km/h will produce blowing snow and limited visibilities today. The strongest winds and lowest visibilities will occur near White Pass on the South Klondike Highway and near Chilkat Pass on the Haines Road. The strong winds and blowing snow will continue through to this evening before abating. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-02T05:14:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-01T13:51:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2763303160.2020
Area: Haines Road - Haines Junction to Pleasant Camp, South Klondike Highway - Carcross to White Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain event by late Monday ... A band of precipitation will cross the province of Quebec from west to east on Monday. While they will fall as snow over most regions further north, rain is expected south of the St Lawrence Valley. Areas along the Valley and especially just north, such as regions in the north shore of Montreal, Laval and the Lower Laurentians, Lanaudière and Mauricie, should receive freezing rain late in the afternoon or evening that could amount for significant freezing rain accumulations. Untreated surfaces, such as roads, walkways and parking lots, could become icy, slippery and dangerous. There may be a significant impact on the afternoon commute Monday evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-02T06:01:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-01T14:02:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0720915934.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Bad weather will occur over Eastern Quebec midweek... A low pressure system will intensify over the Gulf of St. Lawrence on Wednesday. It will bring heavy snowfall accompanied by very strong winds that will cause blowing snow over the Gaspé Peninsula and the North Shore. The Southern Gaspé Peninsula could also see a period of rain or freezing rain. A gradual improvement is expected on Thursday. The poor weather conditions could delay transportation. Please consider modifying any non essential travel plan. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-02T14:24:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-01T22:25:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2171610232.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions near White Pass today and Monday. A Pacific storm continues to bring snow and high winds to White Pass resulting in blizzard conditions. Visibilities will improve beyond 400 metres tonight. However, blizzard conditions will return on Monday near White Pass as the winds pick up again to southwest 60 km/h gusting to 80. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-02T07:01:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-01T15:02:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0713064170.2020
Area: South Klondike Highway - Carcross to White Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain event by late Monday... A band of precipitation will cross the province of Quebec from west to east on Monday. While it will fall as snow over most regions further north, rain is expected south of the St. Lawrence Valley. Areas along the Valley and especially just north, such as the north shore of Montreal, Laval and the Lower Laurentians, Lanaudière, Mauricie and the Quebec City Area will rather receive freezing rain late in the afternoon and/or in the evening. In general, 2 to 5 millimetres of freezing precipitation is expected and possibly up to 10 millimetres locally in areas between Lachute and Lanaudière. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. There may be a significant impact on rush hour traffic in urban areas. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-02T12:23:29-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-01T20:24:29-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2921601940.2020
Area: Mont-Tremblant - Sainte-Agathe area, Sainte-Adèle - Saint-Sauveur area, Saint-Jérôme area, Lachute area, Saint-Eustache area, Laval area, Montréal Island area, Soulanges area, Vaudreuil area, Berthierville - Saint-Gabriel area, Rawdon - Joliette area, Mascouche area, Louiseville area, Lac-aux-Sables area, Shawinigan area, Sainte-Anne-de-la-Pérade area, Trois-Rivières area, Portneuf area, Valcartier - Stoneham area, Québec area, Côte-de-Beaupré - L'Île d'Orléans area, Bellechasse area, Lévis area, Saint-Lambert area, Lotbinière area, Bécancour - Villeroy area, Nicolet area

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain event expected Monday afternoon. A band of rain will move through Eastern Ontario on Monday. Areas along the Ottawa Valley are expected to receive freezing rain in the afternoon into early evening that will cause a thin glaze of ice on untreated surfaces. There may be a significant impact on the Monday afternoon commute. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-02T12:32:18-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A low pressure system tracking eastward through southern Manitoba is giving snow to east-central Manitoba early this morning. The snow will continue today and then taper off from west to east tonight. Snowfall totals are expected to be in the 10 to 20 cm range, with areas between Norway House and Island Lake likely to receive the most. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-02T02:25:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-01T10:26:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4138557734.2020
Area: Molson Lake and Bear Lake, Cross Lake and Jenpeg, Wabowden, Hwy 6 between Little Limestone Lake and Ponton, Norway House, Oxford House and Gods Lake, Red Sucker Lake, Island Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A ridge of high pressure in-line with the Mackenzie River will strengthen tonight, driving strong easterly winds through the Richardson Mountains. Blizzard conditions are expected to develop this evening and persist through to Monday evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-02T12:29:33-00:00

Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Total amounts: 15 to 25 cm. Locations: eastern mainland Nova Scotia. Time span: this evening. Remarks: A trough of low pressure continues to bring heavy snow to eastern parts of the province today, then will taper to light snow and end this evening. For Halifax - East of Porters Lake, the heaviest snowfall is expected to occur over inland areas east of Ship Harbour. Locations further to the west saw less than five centimetres. The system is tracking slightly westward towards Ship Harbour before moving offshore this evening. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-02T01:59:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-01T20:00:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3445041944.2020
Area: Halifax County - east of Porters Lake, Pictou County, Guysborough County, Antigonish County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snow continues. Snow will continue to move northeastward across the region before tapering off from west to east tonight. Local blowing snow may reduce visibility, making travel hazardous at times. Total snowfall accumulations near 15 cm can be expected by the time the snow comes to an end Monday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Total Snowfall amounts: 15 to 25 cm is expected. Locations: Prince Edward Island. Time span: today and this evening. Remarks: A trough of low pressure continues to bring significant snow to the Island today. Amounts are likely to be highly variable across the province, with the highest amounts likely over the northwest. Snow will end this evening as the system moves off to the southeast. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring. Total snowfall: 5 to 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly 70 km/h. Locations: Burin and Avalon Peninsulas. Time span: continuing until midday Monday. Remarks: Fresh snowfall will combine with strengthening northeasterly winds this evening to produce poor visibility in blowing snow. Conditions are expected to improve Monday morning over the Burin Peninsula and near midday over the Avalon Peninsula as the snow tapers off. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-02T11:23:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-01T19:24:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3364866343.2020
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Burin Peninsula
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. A low pressure system which tracked eastward across central Manitoba on Sunday has now moved off into northwestern Ontario. Snow on the back side of the system continues to affect east central Manitoba but will gradually move out of the region later tonight. Snowfall totals are expected to be in the 10 to 20 cm range, with areas between Norway House and Island Lake likely to receive the most. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-02T12:39:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-01T21:14:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0779790733.2020
Area: Poplar River

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. Total Snowfall amounts: 15 to 25 cm. Locations: along the east coast of New Brunswick. Time span: this evening. Remarks: A trough of low pressure continues to bring heavy snow to easternmost parts of the province. The heaviest snowfall accumulations are expected to remain along the coast, with inland areas seeing significantly lesser amounts. The snow will end from north to south through the night tonight as the system moves off to the southeast. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Sudden reduction in visibility in snow and blowing snow will occur this afternoon and early evening as a cold front blasts through southeast Yukon and northern B.C. Areas near Swan Lake and Swift River will be the most affected by the reduced visibilities. Visibilities will improve early this evening as the winds subside in the wake of the front. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-02T04:49:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-01T12:50:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0736472221.2020
Area: Cassiar Mountains
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A snowstorm is expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 25 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly 60 km/h. Locations: St. John's and vicinity and the Southern Shore Time span: continuing until midday Monday. Remarks: Snow will taper to flurries on Monday near noon, with the heaviest snowfall accumulations expected tonight. Gusty northeasterly winds will accompany the snow causing reduced visibilities in blowing snow. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-02T11:22:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-01T19:23:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0670080443.2020
